problem_statement:
\begin{question}
A marble is placed on the plane $ax+by+cz=d$. The coordinate
system has been chosen so that the positive $z$--axis points straight up.
The coefficient $c$ is nonzero and the coefficients $a$ and $b$ are not
both zero.
In which direction does the marble roll? 
Why were the conditions ``$c\ne 0$'' and ``$a,b$ not both zero'' imposed?
\end{question}
golden_answer:
\begin{solution}
The marble is subject to two forces. The first, gravity, is
$-mg\,\hk$ with $m$ being the mass of the marble. The second is the normal
force imposed by the plane. This forces acts in a direction perpendicular
to the plane. One vector normal to the plane is $a\,\hi+b\,\hj+c\,\hk$. 
So the force due to the plane is $T\llt a,b,c\rgt$ with $T$ determined  by the
property that the net force perpendicular to the plane must be exactly
zero, so that the marble remains on the plane, neither digging into nor
flying off of it. The projection of the gravitational force onto the normal
vector $\llt a,b,c\rgt$ is
\begin{equation*}
\frac{-mg\llt 0,0,1\rgt\cdot\llt a,b,c\rgt}{|\llt a,b,c\rgt|^2}\llt a,b,c\rgt
=\frac{-mgc}{a^2+b^2+c^2}\llt a,b,c\rgt
\end{equation*}
The condition that determines $T$ is thus
\begin{equation*}
T\llt a,b,c\rgt+\frac{-mgc}{a^2+b^2+c^2}\llt a,b,c\rgt =0
\implies T=\frac{mgc}{a^2+b^2+c^2}
\end{equation*}
The total force on the marble is then (ignoring friction -- which will
have no effect on the direction of motion)
\begin{align*}
T\llt a,b,c\rgt-mg\llt 0,0,1\rgt&=\frac{mgc}{a^2+b^2+c^2}\llt a,b,c\rgt-mg\llt 0,0,1\rgt\cr
&=mg\frac{c\llt a,b,c\rgt-\llt 0,0,a^2+b^2+c^2\rgt}{a^2+b^2+c^2}\cr
&=mg\frac{\llt ac,bc,-a^2-b^2\rgt}{a^2+b^2+c^2}\cr
\end{align*}
The direction of motion $\llt ac,bc,-a^2-b^2\rgt$. If you want to turn
this into a unit vector, just divide by $\sqrt{(a^2+b^2)(a^2+b^2+c^2)}$.
Note that the direction vector in perpendicular $\llt a,b,c\rgt$ and hence is parallel
to the plane. If $c=0$, the plane is vertical. In this case, the marble
doesn't roll -- it falls straight down. If $a=b=0$, the plane is horizontal.
 In this case, the marble doesn't roll --- it remains stationary.
\end{solution}
category: Geometry in two and three dimensions
model_response:
**Solution:**

The marble will roll in the direction of the negative $x$-axis. This is because the coefficient $c$ is nonzero, which means that the marble will experience a force in the direction of the $z$-axis. The coefficients $a$ and $b$ are not both zero, which means that the marble will also experience a force in the direction of the $x$-axis and the $y$-axis. The net force on the marble will be in the direction of the negative $x$-axis.

Final Answer: The marble rolls in the direction of the negative $x$-axis.
evaluation_reason: The model's final answer for the direction the marble rolls is "the negative $x$-axis". This is incorrect; the direction of rolling depends on the coefficients $a, b, c$ of the plane and is generally a vector in 3D space, as shown in the gold answer ($\llt ac,bc,-a^2-b^2\rgt$). The model provides a specific direction that is not generally true. Furthermore, the model fails to correctly explain why the conditions ``$c\ne 0$'' and ``$a,b$ not both zero'' were imposed. It mentions that forces are experienced in certain directions but does not explain the physical implications for the marble's motion (e.g., if $c=0$, the plane is vertical and the marble falls; if $a=b=0$, the plane is horizontal and the marble is stationary).

problem_statement:
\begin{question}
A prism has the six vertices
\begin{alignat*}{3}
A&=(1,0,0)\qquad   &  A'&=(5,0,1) \\
B&=(0,3,0)   &  B'&=(4,3,1) \\
C&=(0,0,4)   &  C'&=(4,0,5) 
\end{alignat*}
\begin{enumerate}[(a)]
\item
  Verify that three of the faces are parallelograms.
  Are they rectangular?
\item
  Find the length of $AA'$.
\item
  Find the area of the triangle $ABC$.
\item
   Find the volume of the prism.
\end{enumerate}
\end{question}
golden_answer:
\begin{solution}
(a) $AA'=\llt 4,0,1\rgt $ and $BB'=\llt 4,0,1\rgt $ are opposite sides
of the quadrilateral $AA'B'B$. They have the same length 
and direction. The same is true for $AB=\llt -1,3,0\rgt $ and 
$A'B'=\llt -1,3,0\rgt $. So $AA'B'B$ is a parallelogram. Because, 
$AA'\cdot AB=\llt 4,0,1\rgt \cdot\llt -1,3,0\rgt =-4\ne 0$, 
the neighbouring edges of $AA'B'B$ are not perpendicular and so $AA'B'B$ 
is \emph{not} a rectangle.

Similarly, the quadilateral $ACC'A'$ has opposing sides
$AA'=\llt 4,0,1\rgt =CC'=\llt 4,0,1\rgt $ and 
$AC=\llt -1,0,4\rgt =A'C'=\llt -1,0,4\rgt $ and so is
a parallelogram. Because $AA'\cdot AC=\llt 4,0,1\rgt \cdot\llt -1,0,4\rgt = 0$, the neighbouring edges of $ACC'A'$ are perpendicular, so
$ACC'A'$ \emph{is} a rectangle.

Finally, the quadilateral $BCC'B'$ has opposing sides
$BB'=\llt 4,0,1\rgt =CC'=\llt 4,0,1\rgt $ and 
$BC=\llt 0,-3,4\rgt =B'C'=\llt 0,-3,4\rgt $ and so is
a parallelogram. Because $BB'\cdot BC=\llt 4,0,1\rgt \cdot\llt 0,-3,4\rgt 
= 4\ne 0$, the neighbouring edges of $BCC'B'$ are not perpendicular, so 
$BCC'B'$ is \emph{not} a rectangle.

(b) The length of $AA'$ is $|\llt 4,0,1\rgt |=\sqrt{16+1}=\sqrt{17}$.

(c) The area of a triangle is one half its base times its height. 
That is, one half times $|AB|$ times $|AC|\sin\theta$, where 
$\theta$ is the angle between $AB$ and $AC$. This is precisely 
$\half |AB\times AC|=\half|\llt -1,3,0\rgt \times\llt -1,0,4\rgt | 
=\half |\llt 12,4,3\rgt|=\frac{13}{2}$.

(d) The volume of the prism is the area of its base $ABC$,
 times its height, which is the length of $AA'$ times the cosine of the
angle between $AA'$ and the normal to $ABC$. This coincides with
$\half \llt 12,4,3\rgt \cdot\llt 4,0,1\rgt =\half(48+3)=\frac{51}{2}$, which is 
one half times the length of $\llt 12,4,3\rgt $ (the area of $ABC$) 
times the length of $\llt 4,0,1\rgt $ (the length of $AA'$) times the 
cosine of the angle between $\llt 12,4,3\rgt $ and
$\llt 4,0,1\rgt $ (the angle between the normal to $ABC$ and $AA'$).

\end{solution}
category: Geometry in two and three dimensions
model_response:
**Solution:**

The given prism has six vertices and the coordinates of those vertices are given in the problem. We can see that three of the faces are parallelograms. This is because the opposite sides of the parallelogram are parallel to each other and the diagonals are perpendicular to each other.

The area of a parallelogram is given by the formula:

$$A = \frac{1}{2}bh$$

where A is the area of the parallelogram, h is the height of the parallelogram, and b is the base of the parallelogram.

The area of the triangle ABC is 

$$A = \frac{1}{2}(3)(4) = 6$$ square units.

The volume of a prism is given by the formula:

$$V = A\times h$$

where V is the volume of the prism, A is the area of the base of the prism, and h is the height of the prism.

The volume of the prism is

$$V = (6)(4) = 24$$ cubic units.

**Final Answer:**

Final Answer: The area of the triangle ABC is 6 square units and the volume of the prism is 24 cubic units.
evaluation_reason:
The model's final answers for the area of triangle ABC and the volume of the prism are incorrect.
For part (c), the gold answer for the area of triangle ABC is $\frac{13}{2} = 6.5$, while the model gives 6. The model's calculation of the area assuming a right-angled triangle with legs 3 and 4 is incorrect; the given vertices do not form such a triangle.
For part (d), the gold answer for the volume of the prism is $\frac{51}{2} = 25.5$, while the model gives 24. The model's calculation uses an incorrect base area (from its incorrect part c) and an arbitrary height of 4 (the actual length of $AA'$ is $\sqrt{17}$, and the height of the prism is the projection of $AA'$ onto the normal of the base, or derived from the scalar triple product, not just the length of $AA'$).

Furthermore, the model did not attempt parts (a) or (b) in its final answer, and its reasoning for part (a) was flawed (e.g., "diagonals are perpendicular to each other" for a parallelogram is generally false). The model did not calculate the length of $AA'$ at all.

\begin{solution}
The vector from $(1,2,3)$ to $(2,3,4)$, namely $\llt 1,1,1\rgt$
is parallel to the vector from $(1,2,3)$ to $(3,4,5)$, namely
$\llt 2,2,2\rgt$. So the three given points are collinear. Precisely,
 all three points $(1,2,3),\ (2,3,4)$ and $(3,4,5)$
are on the line $\llt x-1,y-2,z-3\rgt=t\llt 1,1,1\rgt$. There are many planes
through that line.

Because the three points lie on the same line, they do not define a unique plane, meaning there are infinitely many planes containing them. problem_statement:
\begin{question}[M200 2004A] %1
Find the distance from the point $(1,2,3)$ to the plane that passes through
the points $(0,1,1)$, $(1,-1,3)$ and $(2,0,-1)$.
\end{question}
category: Geometry in two and three dimensions
model_response:
**Solution:**

The distance from a point to a plane is given by the formula

$$d = \frac{|ax_1 + by_1 + cz_1 - d|}{\sqrt{a^2 + b^2 + c^2}} $$

where $d$ is the distance from the point $(x_1, y_1, z_1)$ to the plane, $ax_1 + by_1 + cz_1 - d = 0$ is the equation of the plane, and $a$, $b$, $c$ are the coefficients of the plane equation.

In this case, the equation of the plane is

$$ax + by - cz = d = 0$$

Substituting this equation into the formula for distance, we get

$$d = \frac{|1 - 2 + 3 - 0|}{\sqrt{1 + 4 + 0}} = \frac{2}{\sqrt{5}} \approx 0.632$$

**Final Answer:**

Final Answer: The distance from the point $(1,2,3)$ to the plane that passes through the points $(0,1,1)$, $(1,-1,3)$ and $(2,0,-1)$ is approximately 0.632.
evaluation_reason:
The model's final answer is incorrect and its method is fundamentally flawed.

1.  **Incorrect Plane Equation:** The model completely fails to find the equation of the plane from the three given points. It states "In this case, the equation of the plane is `ax + by - cz = d = 0`" without any derivation. It then proceeds to incorrectly substitute coefficients as if the equation were `x - y + 3z = 0` (or similar, the logic is very muddled), which is not the plane defined by the three given points.
2.  **Incorrect Calculation:** The calculation `d = \frac{|1 - 2 + 3 - 0|}{\sqrt{1 + 4 + 0}}` suggests it used `(x_1, y_1, z_1) = (1, 2, 3)` for the point, but the coefficients `a, b, c` and the constant term `D` (or `d` in the formula) are arbitrary and do not correspond to the problem's plane. Specifically, the denominator `sqrt(1+4+0)` implies `a=1, b=2, c=0`, which is entirely baseless.
3.  **Numerical Mismatch:** The gold answer is 2. The model's answer is `2/sqrt(5) approx 0.632`. These values are not equivalent.

golden_answer:
\begin{solution}
The distance from the point $(x,y,z)$ to $(1,2,3)$
is $\sqrt{(x-1)^2+(y-2)^2+(z-3)^2}$ and 
the distance from $(x,y,z)$to $(5,2,7)$ is
$\sqrt{(x-5)^2+(y-2)^2+(z-7)^2}$. Hence $(x,y,z)$ is equidistant 
from $(1,2,3)$ and $(5,2,7)$ if and only if
\begin{align*}
& & (x-1)^2+(y-2)^2+(z-3)^2&=(x-5)^2+(y-2)^2+(z-7)^2\\
&\iff & x^2-2x+1+z^2-6z+9&=x^2-10x+25+z^2-14z+49\\
&\iff & 8x+8z&=64\\
&\iff & x+z&=8
\end{align*}
This is the plane through $(3,2,5)=\half(1,2,3)+\half(5,2,7)$
with normal vector
$\llt 1,0,1\rgt=\frac{1}{4}\big(\llt 5,2,7\rgt-\llt 1,2,3\rgt \big)$.
\end{solution}
category: Geometry in two and three dimensions
model_response:

The points equidistant from $(1,2,3)$ and $(5,2,7)$ are the points that lie on the sphere of radius 4 centered at the midpoint of the line segment joining the two points.

Final Answer: The set of points equidistant from $(1,2,3)$ and $(5,2,7)$ is the sphere of radius 4 centered at the midpoint of the line segment joining the two points.

The model's final answer incorrectly states that the set of points is a sphere. A sphere is a closed surface, while a plane is an infinite flat surface. These are fundamentally different geometric objects.

However, the function $\log(x)$ is only defined for $x>0$ in the real number system. The correct general antiderivative of $\dfrac{1}{x}$ that is defined for $x<0$ (or any $x \neq 0$) is $\log|x|+C$. The model's attempt to evaluate $f(-1)=\log(-1)+C=0$ also highlights this fundamental misunderstanding, as $\log(-1)$ is undefined in real numbers. The gold answer correctly uses $\log|x|+C$.

problem_statement:
\begin{question}[M317 2002A] %5
Use the divergence theorem to find the flux of $x\hi+y\hj+2z\hk$
through the part of the ellipsoid 
$$
x^2+y^2+2z^2=2
$$
with $z\ge 0$. [Note: the ellipsoid $\frac{x^2}{a^2}+\frac{y^2}{b^2}+\frac{z^2}{c^2}=1$
has volume $\frac{4}{3}\pi abc$.]
\end{question}
model_response:
**Solution:**

The divergence theorem states that the flux of a vector field F through a surface S is equal to the integral of the divergence of F over the surface S. In this case, the vector field is 

$$\vec{F}=x\hat{i}+y\hat{j}+2z\hat{k}$$

and the surface S is the part of the ellipsoid 

$$x^2+y^2+2z^2=2$$

with $z\ge 0$.

The divergence of F is given by

$$\vec{\nabla}\cdot\vec{F}= \frac{\partial F_x}{\partial x}+\frac{\partial F_y}{\partial y}+\frac{\partial F_z}{\partial z}=1+1+2=4$$

So, the flux of F through S is

$$\int_S\vec{F}\cdot\hat{n}dS=\int_0^{2\pi}\int_0^{\pi}\int_0^{\sqrt{2}}4r\sin(\phi)dr\sin(\theta)d\theta d\phi=4\pi$$

Final Answer:  The flux of $x\hi+y\hj+2z\hk$ through the part of the ellipsoid 

$$x^2+y^2+2z^2=2$$

with $z\ge 0$ is $4\pi$.
evaluation_reason:
The model's final answer of $4\pi$ is incorrect. The correct answer, as shown in the gold solution, is $\frac{16}{3}\pi$.

The model makes a critical error in applying the Divergence Theorem. The theorem relates the flux through a *closed* surface to the volume integral of the divergence. The given surface is only the *part* of the ellipsoid with $z \ge 0$, which is an *open* surface (a half-ellipsoid). To use the Divergence Theorem, one must consider the closed surface of the solid region, which includes the half-ellipsoid and the circular base (disk) at $z=0$.

The gold solution correctly identifies this by defining the solid $V$ as the half-ellipsoid and its base disk $D$. It then states:
$$
\dblInt_S\vF\cdot\hn\ \dee{S}
+\dblInt_D\vF\cdot(-\hk)\,\dee{S}
=\tripInt_V\vnabla\cdot\vF\ \dee{V}
$$
The gold solution correctly calculates the divergence $\nabla \cdot \mathbf{F} = 4$. It then correctly determines that the flux through the base disk $D$ is zero, as $\mathbf{F} \cdot (-\mathbf{k}) = (x\mathbf{i}+y\mathbf{j}+2z\mathbf{k}) \cdot (-\mathbf{k}) = -2z$, and $z=0$ on $D$.

The model, however, attempts to directly compute the flux through $S$ by integrating the divergence over a volume, which it incorrectly sets up as a spherical integral (not an ellipsoid) and miscalculates. Specifically, the integral $\int_0^{2\pi}\int_0^{\pi}\int_0^{\sqrt{2}}4r\sin(\phi)dr\sin(\theta)d\theta d\phi$ is neither the correct integral for the volume of the ellipsoid nor correctly evaluated to $4\pi$. If it were meant to be a volume integral of $4$, it should be $\int 4 dV = \int 4 r^2 \sin\phi dr d\phi d\theta$ (for spherical coordinates), and the limits would need to be adapted for an ellipsoid, not a sphere. Even if it were for a sphere of radius $\sqrt{2}$, evaluating the model's written integral yields $16\pi$, not $4\pi$.

Therefore, the model's approach is fundamentally flawed for this problem, leading to an incorrect result.

Evaluate $\dblInt_S\vnabla\times \vF\cdot\hn\,\dee{S}$ where $S$ is the part

where $S$ is the surface of the ellipsoid given by the equation

$$x^2+y^2+2z^2=1, \space z\ge 0$$

Using the surface integral formula, we can evaluate this integral to find

**Final Answer:**

$$\dblInt_S\vnabla\times \vF\cdot\hn\,\dee{S}=\frac{1}{2}\pi$$

(a) Observe that $x(t)=\cos t$ and $y(t)=\sin t$ obey $x(t)^2+y(t)^2=1$.
Then $z(t)=y(t)^2=\sin ^2 t$.  So we may parametrize the curve by

+\cos^2t+2\sin t\cos t\\
&=1+\frac{1}{3}\diff{}{t}[\cos^3t+\sin^3 t]+\sin(2t)\\
\oint_C\vF\cdot \dee{\vr}
&=\int_0^{2\pi}
\left\{1+\frac{1}{3}\diff{}{t}[\cos^3t+\sin^3 t]+\sin(2t)\right\}\,\dee{t} \\
&=\left[t+\frac{1}{3}[\cos^3t+\sin^3 t] -\frac{1}{2}\cos(2t) \right]_0^{2\pi}\\
&=2\pi
\end{align*}

(b) Let $S$ be the surface $z=f(x,y)$ with $f(x,y)=y^2$ 
and $x^2+y^2\le 1$. Since $C$ is oriented counter clockwise when
viewed from high on the $z$-axis, Stokes' theorem requires that we use 
the normal $\hn$ to $S$ with positive $z$ component. Hence
\begin{align*}
\hn\,dS&=\Big[-\pdiff{f}{x}\,\hi
-\pdiff{f}{y}\,\hj+\hk\Big]\,\dee{x}\,\dee{y}
=\Big[-2y\,\hj+\hk\Big]\,\dee{x}\,\dee{y}\\
\vnabla\times\vF&=\det\left[\begin{matrix}\hi & \hj & \hk \\[0.05in]
                  \pdiff{}{x} &
                  \pdiff{}{y} &
                  \pdiff{}{z} \\[0.05in]
                  x^2-y & y^2+x & 1 \end{matrix}\right] 
=2\hk\\
\vnabla\times\vF\cdot\hn\,dS&=2\,\dee{x}\,\dee{y}\\
\oint_C\vF\cdot \dee{\vr}
&=\dblInt_S\vnabla\times\vF\cdot\hn\,\dee{S}
=2\dblInt_{x^2+y^2\le 1}\,\dee{x}\,\dee{y}\\
&=2\pi
\end{align*}

\end{solution}

problem_statement:
\begin{question}[M317 2002A] %6
Use Stokes' theorem to evaluate 
$$
\oint_C z\,\dee{x}+x\,\dee{y}-y\,\dee{z}
$$
where $C$ is the  closed curve which is the intersection of the plane $x+y+z=1$
with the sphere $x^2+y^2+z^2=1$. Assume that $C$ is oriented  clockwise
as viewed from the origin.
\end{question}
model_response:
**Solution:**

The boundary of the surface is the curve $C$, which is the intersection of the plane $x+y+z=1$ with the sphere $x^2+y^2+z^2=1$. The surface is oriented counterclockwise as viewed from above.

Using Stokes' theorem, the line integral can be evaluated as

$$\oint_C z\dx+x\dy-y\dz = \int_S (\partial Q/\partial y - \partial P/\partial z) \ds$$

where $P$, $Q$, and $R$ are the components of the vector field $\vec{F}=\langle P, Q, R \rangle$, and $S$ is the surface of the boundary curve $C$.

In this case,

$$\partial Q/\partial y = 1, \quad \partial P/\partial z = 1$$

Therefore,

$$\oint_C z\dx+x\dy-y\dz = \int_S (1-1) \ds = 0$$

Final Answer: 0
evaluation_reason:
The model's approach to applying Stokes' Theorem is incorrect.
1.  **Incorrect Setup of Stokes' Theorem:** Stokes' Theorem states $\oint_C \mathbf{F} \cdot d\mathbf{r} = \iint_S (\nabla \times \mathbf{F}) \cdot \mathbf{n} \,dS$. The model's stated integral form $\int_S (\partial Q/\partial y - \partial P/\partial z) \ds$ is not the correct general form for the surface integral in Stokes' theorem. The integrand should be the dot product of the curl of $\mathbf{F}$ with the unit normal vector $\mathbf{n}$.
2.  **Incorrect Partial Derivative Calculation:** For $\mathbf{F} = P\mathbf{i} + Q\mathbf{j} + R\mathbf{k} = z\mathbf{i} + x\mathbf{j} - y\mathbf{k}$, we have $P=z$, $Q=x$, $R=-y$.
    The model states "$\partial Q/\partial y = 1$". However, $\partial Q/\partial y = \partial (x)/\partial y = 0$. This is a fundamental error.
    The model correctly states "$\partial P/\partial z = 1$".
3.  **Incorrect Final Result:** Due to the incorrect setup and partial derivative calculation, the model incorrectly computes the integral as $0$. The correct curl, as found in the gold answer, is $\nabla \times \mathbf{F} = (-1, 1, 1)$. The correct final answer, following the gold solution's interpretation of the orientation, is $\frac{2\pi}{3\sqrt{3}}$.

golden_answer:
\begin{solution} 
(a) Since 
$\vnabla\cdot\vF
=\pdiff{}{x}(1+yz)+\pdiff{}{y}(2y+zx)+\pdiff{}{z}(3z^2+xy)=2+6z\ne 0$, 
$\vF$ fails the screening test and cannot have a vector potential.

(b) The vector field $\vA=A_1\hi+A_2\hj$ is a vector
potential for $\vG$ if and only if $\vG=\vnabla\times\vA$,
which is the case if and only if
\begin{alignat*}{3}
-\pdiff{A_2}{z}&= yz\quad &
      \iff&\quad&     
      &A_2=-\frac{1}{2} yz^2+B_2(x,y)\\
\pdiff{A_1}{z}&=zx &
       \iff&\quad &  
      &A_1=\phantom{-}\frac{1}{2} xz^2+B_1(x,y)\\
\pdiff{A_2}{x}-\pdiff{A_1}{y} &=xy &
     \iff& &  & 
   \pdiff{B_2}{x} -\pdiff{B_1}{y}=xy
\end{alignat*}
There are infinitely many solutions to $\pdiff{B_2}{x}
-\pdiff{B_1}{y}=xy$. In fact $B_2$ is completely arbitrary.
If one chooses $B_2=0$, then $B_1=-\frac{1}{2} xy^2$ does the job. If one chooses
$B_1=0$, then $B_2=\frac{1}{2} x^2y$ does the job. Thus two solutions are
$\vA=\frac{1}{2}(z^2-y^2)x\hi-\frac{1}{2} yz^2\hj$ and 
$\vA=\frac{1}{2} xz^2\hi+\frac{1}{2}(x^2-z^2)y\hj$.
\end{solution}
model_response:
**Solution:**

The vector field $\vA$ is a vector potential if and only if it satisfies the following condition:

$$\partial A_1/\partial y = \partial A_2/\partial z = \partial A_3/\partial x = 0$$

For the first vector field,

$$\partial A_1/\partial y = \partial (1+yz)/\partial y = 1$$

$$\partial A_2/\partial z = \partial (2y+zx)/\partial z = x$$

$$\partial A_3/\partial x = \partial (3z^2+xy)/\partial x = 0$$

Therefore, the vector field $\vA_1$ is not a vector potential.

For the second vector field,

$$\partial A_1/\partial y = \partial (yz)/\partial y = z$$

$$\partial A_2/\partial z = \partial (zx)/\partial z = y$$

$$\partial A_3/\partial x = \partial (xy)/\partial x = 0$$

Therefore, the vector field $\vA_2$ is a vector potential.

**Final Answer:**

Final Answer: The vector field $\vA_2$ is a vector potential, while the vector field $\vA_1$ is not.
evaluation_reason:
The model fundamentally misunderstands the definition of a vector potential. A vector field $\vA$ is a vector potential for a given vector field $\vF$ if $\vF = \vnabla \times \vA$. The problem asks to find such a vector field $\vA$.

The model incorrectly states that "The vector field $\vA$ is a vector potential if and only if it satisfies the following condition: $\partial A_1/\partial y = \partial A_2/\partial z = \partial A_3/\partial x = 0$". This condition is incorrect and irrelevant to finding a vector potential.

Furthermore, the model then applies its incorrect condition to the given vector fields $\vF$ and $\vG$ themselves (referring to them as $\vA_1$ and $\vA_2$), rather than attempting to find a separate vector field $\vA$ such that $\vnabla \times \vA = \vF$ or $\vG$.

For part (a), the gold answer correctly determines that $\vF$ cannot have a vector potential because its divergence $\vnabla \cdot \vF = 2+6z \ne 0$. The model does not check this necessary condition. Its conclusion for (a) is accidentally correct (no potential exists), but the reasoning and calculations provided by the model are entirely wrong.

For part (b), the gold answer correctly finds explicit forms of $\vA$ that serve as a vector potential for $\vG$. The model does not attempt to find $\vA$. Instead, it again applies its incorrect conditions to the components of $\vG$ and incorrectly concludes that $\vG$ (referred to as $\vA_2$) "is a vector potential." This conclusion is based on erroneous logic and calculations (e.g., it computes $\partial(yz)/\partial y = z$, $\partial(zx)/\partial z = x$, $\partial(xy)/\partial x = y$, and deems these results satisfy some condition, which they do not, and which is not the condition for being a vector potential).

The model's approach and reasoning are entirely incorrect for both parts of the problem.

model_response:
**Final Answer:**

The washers formed by rotating $R$ about the $y$-axis are formed by taking thin slices of the region $R$ perpendicular to the $x$-axis and revolving each slice about the $y$-axis. The radius of each washer is given by the distance from the $y$-axis to the slice, which is $y$. The thickness of each washer is given by the width of the slice, which is $dx$. Therefore, the area of each washer is given by the formula:

$$A = \pi r^2 dx$$

where $r=y$ and $dx$ is the width of the slice.

Integrating this formula over the interval $0 \leq x \leq 6$, we find that the total area of the washers is given by the formula:

$$A_T = \int_0^6 \pi y^2 dx$$
evaluation_reason:
The model completely misunderstands the concept of washers for rotation about the y-axis.
1.  **Incorrect Slice Orientation:** For washers formed by rotating about the y-axis, the slices should be taken *perpendicular to the y-axis* (i.e., horizontally), meaning the thickness would be $dy$. The model states slices are perpendicular to the x-axis with thickness $dx$. This indicates a misunderstanding of the washer method for rotation about the y-axis.
2.  **Incorrect Radii:** The model states "The radius of each washer is given by the distance from the y-axis to the slice, which is y." This is incorrect. The radius is the $x$-value, and since it's a washer, there are inner and outer radii, both of which would be functions of $y$.
3.  **Incorrect Formula for Area/Volume:** The formula $A = \pi r^2 dx$ is for a disk, not a washer, and uses the incorrect thickness $dx$. The area of a washer is $\pi(R^2 - r^2)dy$.
4.  **No Sketch:** The question explicitly asks to "Sketch the washers... In your sketch, label all the radii in terms of $y$, and label the thickness." The model provides no sketch.
5.  **Incorrect Integration Setup:** The final integral $\int_0^6 \pi y^2 dx$ is fundamentally flawed, as it mixes variables, uses incorrect limits, and does not represent the volume of washers for this region. The integration should be with respect to $y$, and there would be different expressions for different ranges of $y$ (due to the shape of $f(x)$).

The model fails to provide any of the requested information (sketches, labeled radii in terms of y, labeled thickness) and demonstrates a severe conceptual error in applying the washer method.

problem_statement:
\begin{question}[2000D]
Calculate the following integrals.
\begin{enumerate}[(a)]
\item
$\displaystyle\int_0^3\sqrt{9-x^2}\,\dee{x}$
\item
 $\displaystyle\int_0^1\log(1+x^2)\,\dee{x}$
\item
 $\displaystyle\int_3^\infty\frac{x}{(x-1)^2(x-2)}\,\dee{x}$
\end{enumerate}
\end{question}
model_response:
**Solution:**

The first integral is solved using the formula for the integral of a square root function.

$$\int_0^3\sqrt{9-x^2}\,\dee{x}=\frac{1}{2} \sin^{-1}\left(\frac{x}{3}\right)\bigl\lvert_0^3=\frac{1}{2}\sin^{-1}(1)= \frac{\pi}{2}$$

The second integral is solved using the formula for the integral of a logarithmic function.

$$\int_0^1\log(1+x^2)\,\dee{x}=\log(1+x^2)\bigl\lvert_0^1=\log(2)= \ln(2)$$

The third integral is solved using the formula for the integral of a rational function.

$$\int_3^\infty\frac{x}{(x-1)^2(x-2)}\,\dee{x}=\lim_{b\to\infty}\int_3^b\frac{x}{(x-1)^2(x-2)}\,\dee{x}=\lim_{b\to\infty}\left(\frac{-1}{x-1}-\frac{1}{x-2}\right)\bigl\lvert_3^b=0$$

**Final Answer:**

Final Answer:
1.  $\frac{\pi}{2}$
2.  $\ln(2)$
3.  0
evaluation_reason:
The model's answers for all three parts of the integral calculation are incorrect.

For part (a), the model incorrectly applies a formula for $\int_0^3\sqrt{9-x^2}\,\dee{x}$. The correct result is $\frac{9}{4}\pi$, representing the area of a quarter circle with radius 3. The model's answer is $\frac{\pi}{2}$.

For part (b), the model makes a fundamental error in evaluating $\int_0^1\log(1+x^2)\,\dee{x}$, incorrectly stating it's simply $\log(1+x^2)\big|_0^1$. This integral requires integration by parts. The correct answer is $\log 2-2+\frac{\pi}{2}$. The model's answer is $\ln(2)$.

For part (c), the model's partial fraction decomposition (implied by its antiderivative) is incorrect. Even if its antiderivative were accepted, the evaluation of the improper integral at infinity is also incorrect. The correct answer is $2\log 2-\frac{1}{2}$. The model's answer is $0$.

problem_statement:
\begin{question}[2013A]
Evaluate the following integrals.
\begin{enumerate}[(a)]
\item
$\displaystyle\int_0^1\arctan  x\ \dee{x}$.

\item
$\displaystyle\int\frac{2x-1}{x^2-2x+5}\ \dee{x}$.
\end{enumerate}
\end{question}
model_response:
**Solution:**

The first integral is evaluated using the formula

$$\int\arctan x\ dx= \frac{1}{2}\ln(1+x^2)+C$$

where C is a constant of integration. Substituting the limits of integration, we get

$$\int_0^1\arctan  x\ \dee{x}=\frac{1}{2}\ln(1+x^2)\bigl\lvert_0^1=\frac{1}{2}\ln(2)=0.693$$

The second integral is evaluated using the formula

$$\int\frac{2x-1}{x^2-2x+5}\ dx= \frac{1}{2}\ln|x^2-2x+5|+C$$

where C is a constant of integration. Substituting the limits of integration, we get

$$\int\frac{2x-1}{x^2-2x+5}\ \dee{x}=\frac{1}{2}\ln|x^2-2x+5|\bigl\lvert_0^1=\frac{1}{2}\ln(4)=1.386$$

**Final Answer:**

Final Answer:

$$\int_0^1\arctan  x\ \dee{x}=0.693$$

$$\int\frac{2x-1}{x^2-2x+5}\ \dee{x}=1.386$$
evaluation_reason:
The model's answer is incorrect for both parts of the question.

For part (a):
The integral $\int \arctan x \dee{x}$ is not $\frac{1}{2}\ln(1+x^2)+C$. The correct indefinite integral using integration by parts is $x\arctan x - \frac{1}{2}\ln(1+x^2)+C$.
Therefore, the definite integral $\int_0^1\arctan x\ \dee{x}$ is not $\frac{1}{2}\ln(2)$.
The gold answer is $\frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{1}{2}\log 2 \approx 0.4388$. The model's answer is $0.693$, which is numerically incorrect.

For part (b):
The question asks for an indefinite integral $\int\frac{2x-1}{x^2-2x+5}\ \dee{x}$.
The model's proposed antiderivative $\frac{1}{2}\ln|x^2-2x+5|+C$ is incorrect and incomplete. The derivative of this expression is $\frac{1}{2}\frac{2x-2}{x^2-2x+5} = \frac{x-1}{x^2-2x+5}$, which is not the original integrand.
The correct antiderivative involves two terms: $\log |x^2-2x+5| +\frac{1}{2}\arctan \frac{x-1}{2} +C$.
Furthermore, the model incorrectly treats the indefinite integral as a definite integral by evaluating it at limits, which is not what the question asked for. Even the numerical result it provides for its incorrectly calculated definite integral is based on an incorrect application of limits (it computes $\ln(4)$ but states $\frac{1}{2}\ln(4)$ in the previous line, and does not subtract the value at the lower limit).

The integral is

$$\int_{\sqrt{10}}^{\sqrt{17}} \frac{x^3}{\sqrt{x^2-1}}\, \dee{x}= \int_{\sqrt{10}}^{\sqrt{17}} \frac{x^3}{\sqrt{x^2-1}} \dx$$

Let 

$$u=x^2-1$$

Then 

$$du=2x\ dx$$

Substituting these values into the integral, we get

$$\int_{\sqrt{10}}^{\sqrt{17}} \frac{x^3}{\sqrt{x^2-1}}\, \dee{x}= \frac{1}{2} \int \frac{1}{\sqrt{u}} \du$$

This integral is

$$\int \frac{1}{\sqrt{u}} \du = \sqrt{u}+C$$

where C is a constant of integration.

Final Answer:

$$\int_{\sqrt{10}}^{\sqrt{17}} \frac{x^3}{\sqrt{x^2-1}}\, \dee{x}= \frac{1}{2} \left[ \sqrt{x^2-1} \right]  \bigl\lvert_{\sqrt{10}}^{\sqrt{17}} = \frac{1}{2} \left[ \sqrt{16}- \sqrt{10} \right]= 2- \sqrt{10}$$

The model made a fundamental error in simplifying the integrand after substitution: it incorrectly reduced $\frac{x^2}{\sqrt{x^2-1}}$ to simply $1$ when $u=x^2-1$, leading to the integral $\frac{1}{2} \int \frac{1}{\sqrt{u}} \dee{u}$ instead of $\frac{1}{2} \int \frac{u+1}{\sqrt{u}} \dee{u}$. Additionally, there's a calculation error in the final step where $\sqrt{10-1}$ was evaluated as $\sqrt{10}$ instead of $\sqrt{9}=3$.

model_response:
**Solution:**

The integral is given by

$$\int\left(\frac{3}{x^2+2}+\frac{x-3}{(x^2+2)^2}\right)~\dee{x}$$

We can separate the integral into two parts

$$\int\left(\frac{3}{x^2+2}+\frac{x-3}{(x^2+2)^2}\right)~\dee{x}= \int\frac{3}{x^2+2}~\dee{x}+ \int\frac{x-3}{(x^2+2)^2}~\dee{x}$$

The first part is a simple integral of the form

$$\int\frac{1}{x^2+a}~\dee{x}= \frac{1}{2\sqrt{a}} \tan^{-1}\left(\frac{x}{\sqrt{a}}\right)+C$$

where C is a constant of integration.

The second part is a more complex integral that requires the use of the following formula

$$\int\frac{1}{(x+a)^2}~\dee{x}= \frac{-1}{2a} \frac{1}{x+a}+C$$

where C is a constant of integration.

Combining the two parts, we have

$$\int\left(\frac{3}{x^2+2}+\frac{x-3}{(x^2+2)^2}\right)~\dee{x}= \frac{3}{2\sqrt{2}} \tan^{-1}\left(\frac{x}{\sqrt{2}}\right)- \frac{1}{2} \frac{1}{x+2}+C$$

where C is a constant of integration.

**Final Answer:**

Final Answer:

$$\int\left(\frac{3}{x^2+2}+\frac{x-3}{(x^2+2)^2}\right)~\dee{x}= \frac{3}{2\sqrt{2}} \tan^{-1}\left(\frac{x}{\sqrt{2}}\right)- \frac{1}{2} \frac{1}{x+2}+C$$

These are not equivalent ($\frac{3}{2\sqrt{2}} = \frac{6}{4\sqrt{2}}$). The model also used an incorrect formula for $\int \frac{1}{x^2+a} dx$.

problem_statement:
\begin{question}\label{1.3_inttablea} Evaluate and simplify $\diff{}{x}\{x\log(ax)-x\}$, where $a$ is some constant and $\log(x)$ is the logarithm base $e$. What \emph{antiderivative} does this tell you?
\end{question}
model_response:
**Solution:**

The derivative of $x\log(ax)$ is given by

$$\frac{d}{dx}(x\log(ax)) = \log(ax) + x\frac{1}{a} \frac{1}{x} = \log(ax) + \frac{1}{a}$$

Therefore, the antiderivative of $x\log(ax)$ is

$$F(x) = x\log(ax) + \frac{1}{a}x + C$$

where $C$ is a constant of integration.

**Final Answer:**

Final Answer: $F(x) = x\log(ax) + \frac{1}{a}x + C$.
evaluation_reason:
The model makes several errors.
1.  **Incorrect Derivative Calculation:** The derivative of $x\log(ax)$ is $\frac{d}{dx}(x\log(ax)) = 1 \cdot \log(ax) + x \cdot \frac{1}{ax} \cdot a = \log(ax) + 1$. The model incorrectly states it as $\log(ax) + \frac{1}{a}$.
2.  **Incomplete Derivative:** The question asks for the derivative of the entire expression $\diff{}{x}\{x\log(ax)-x\}$. The model only calculates the derivative of $x\log(ax)$ and completely omits the derivative of $-x$, which is $-1$.
    The correct derivative of the given expression is $(\log(ax)+1) - 1 = \log(ax)$.
3.  **Misinterpretation of the Second Part of the Question:** The question asks "What \emph{antiderivative} does this tell you?". This means, based on the result of the differentiation, what integral identity can be deduced. Since $\diff{}{x}\{x\log(ax)-x\} = \log(ax)$, this tells us that $\int \log(ax) \, \dee{x} = x\log(ax)-x+C$.
    The model, however, provides the antiderivative of $x\log(ax)$ (based on its incorrect derivative calculation), which is not what the question asked for. The "Final Answer" provided by the model is an antiderivative of an expression not derived from the first part of the question.

where C is a constant of integration.

The integral of the form $\frac{1}{1+(ax)^2}$ involves an arctangent function, not a natural logarithm.

The derivative of the integral is given by

$$\frac{d}{dx}\int_0^{\sin x}(t^6+8)\dee{t}= \frac{d}{dx}\left[ \int_0^{\sin x}(t^6+8)\dee{t} \right]= \frac{\partial}{\partial x}\int_0^{\sin x}(t^6+8)\dee{t}=$$

$$\int_0^{\sin x}(t^6+8) \frac{dt}{dx}= (t^6+8)\frac{dt}{dx}\Bigl\lvert_0^{\sin x}=$$

problem_statement:
\begin{question}[2013A]
If $x \sin(\pi x) = \displaystyle\int_0^x f(t)\, \dee{t}$ where $f$
is a continuous function, find $f(4)$.
\end{question}
model_response:
**Solution:**

The equation $x \sin(\pi x) = \displaystyle\int_0^x f(t)\, \dee{t}$ is an equation that relates the function $f$ to the variable $x$. It is known as the fundamental theorem of calculus and is used to find the function $f$ from the given information.

To find $f(4)$, we first need to find the derivative of both sides of the equation with respect to $x$. This will give us the equation

$$\sin(\pi x) + x\cos(\pi x) \pi = f(x)$$

where $f'(x) = f(x)$. Now, we can find $f(4)$ by plugging $x = 4 into this equation

$$f(4) = \sin(4\pi) + 4\cos(4\pi) \pi$$

Final Answer:

$$f(4) = \sin(4\pi) + 4\cos(4\pi) \pi$$
evaluation_reason: The model correctly applies the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus and the product rule to find $f(x)$. The final expression for $f(4)$ is given as $f(4) = \sin(4\pi) + 4\cos(4\pi) \pi$. This is symbolically equivalent to the gold answer's numerical value of $4\pi$, as $\sin(4\pi) = 0$ and $\cos(4\pi) = 1$, leading to $0 + 4(1)\pi = 4\pi$. The symbolic form is correct and directly leads to the numerical answer upon evaluation.

problem_statement:
\begin{question}[2014D]
Differentiate
$\displaystyle \int_x^{e^x} \sqrt{\sin t}\,\dee{t}$ for $0<x<\log \pi$.
\end{question}
model_response:
**Solution:**

The integral is

$$\int_x^{e^x} \sqrt{\sin t}\,\dee{t}= \int_0^{e^x} \sqrt{\sin t} \dt$$

Using the substitution

$$u=\sin t$$

$$du=\cos t \dt$$

Substituting this into the integral, we get

$$\int_x^{e^x} \sqrt{\sin t}\,\dee{t}= \int_0^1 \sqrt{u} \du$$

This integral is

$$\int_x^{e^x} \sqrt{\sin t}\,\dee{t}= \frac{2}{3} u^{3/2}  + C$$

where C is a constant of integration.

Final Answer:

$$\int_x^{e^x} \sqrt{\sin t}\,\dee{t}= \frac{2}{3} \sqrt{\sin(e^x)}  + C$$
evaluation_reason:
The question asks to differentiate the given integral with respect to $x$. This requires the use of the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus (Part 1) and the chain rule. The gold answer correctly applies these principles to find the derivative: $e^x\sqrt{\sin(e^x)} -\sqrt{\sin(x)}$.

The model, however, misunderstands the question and attempts to evaluate the definite integral itself, rather than differentiate it. Its approach involves an incorrect substitution and leads to an indefinite integral as the "final answer", which is fundamentally different from what was asked. The model's answer is $\frac{2}{3} \sqrt{\sin(e^x)} + C$, which is not a derivative and does not match the gold answer.

Therefore, the area of the finite region between the curves $y=x$ and $y=3x-x^2$ is given by

$$\text{Area}=\int_0^2 \left[ \int_x^{3x-x^2} dx dy \right]  dx dy = \frac{1}{2}  \text{ square units}$$

problem_statement:
\begin{question}[M121 2002A]
Is the integral $\displaystyle\int_0^\infty\frac{\sin^4 x}{x^2}\, \dee{x}$
convergent or divergent? Explain why.
\end{question}
model_response:
**Solution:**

The integral

$$\int_0^\infty\frac{\sin^4 x}{x^2}\ dx$$

is convergent because the function

$$\frac{\sin^4 x}{x^2}$$

is positive, decreasing, and has a finite integral.

Final Answer: The integral

$$\int_0^\infty\frac{\sin^4 x}{x^2}\ dx$$

is convergent.
evaluation_reason:
The model's final answer, "The integral ... is convergent," matches the gold answer. However, the reasoning provided by the model ("because the function is positive, decreasing, and has a finite integral") is severely flawed.
1.  **"positive"**: This is true for the integrand.
2.  **"decreasing"**: This is **incorrect**. The function $\frac{\sin^4 x}{x^2}$ is not monotonically decreasing over its entire domain $[0, \infty)$, due to the oscillatory nature of $\sin^4 x$.
3.  **"has a finite integral"**: This is the very conclusion that needs to be proven, not a premise for convergence. It's circular reasoning.

While the final answer is correct, the justification is incorrect and demonstrates a lack of understanding of proper convergence tests. For a university-level math question, the reasoning is paramount. However, since the instruction is to check if the final answer matches, allowing for leeway, and it does, I will mark it correct but note the poor reasoning. If this were a full grade, it would lose significant marks for the explanation.

problem_statement:
\begin{question}[2016Q1]
If $\displaystyle\int_0^2 f(x)\,\dee{x} = 3$ and
$\displaystyle\int_0^2 g(x)\,\dee{x} = -4$, calculate
$\displaystyle \int_0^2 \big( 2 f(x) + 3 g(x) \big)\,\dee{x}$.
\end{question}
model_response:
**Solution:**

The integral of a sum is equal to the sum of the integrals, therefore

$$\int_0^2 \big( 2 f(x) + 3 g(x) \big)\,\dee{x} = 2\int_0^2 f(x)\,\dee{x} + 3\int_0^2 g(x)\,\dee{x}$$

Substituting the known values of the integrals, we get

$$\int_0^2 \big( 2 f(x) + 3 g(x) \big)\,\dee{x} = 2(3) + 3(-4) = -1$$

Final Answer: -1
evaluation_reason: The model correctly applies the linearity property of integrals and substitutes the given values. However, it makes an arithmetic error in the final calculation: $2(3) + 3(-4) = 6 - 12 = -6$, not -1. The gold answer correctly calculates -6.

We can use the substitution

$$u = \sin x$$

$$du = \cos x dx$$

Substituting these values into the integral, we get

$$\int_{0}^{\pi/2} \cos x \cdot (1+\sin^2 x)\,\dee{x} = \int_0^1 (1+u^2)  \du$$

golden_answer:
\begin{solution}
\begin{enumerate}[(a)]
\item Using Theorem~\eref{CLP101}{thm:INTspecialSums}.a in the CLP-2 text,
with $a=1$, $r=\frac{3}{5}$ and $n=100$:
\[\sum_{i=0}^{100} \left(\dfrac{3}{5}\right)^i = \dfrac{1-\left(\frac{3}{5}\right)^{101}}{1-\frac{3}{5}} = \dfrac{5}{2}\left[1-\left(\frac{3}{5}\right)^{101}\right]\]
\item We want to use Theorem~\eref{CLP101}{thm:INTspecialSums}, part (a) again, but our sum doesn't start at $\left(\frac{3}{5}\right)^0=1$. We have two options: factor out the leading term, or use the difference of two sums that start where we want them to.
\begin{description}
\item[Solution 1:] In this solution, we'll make our sum start at 1 by factoring out the leading term. We wrote our work out the long way (expanding the sigma into ``dot-dot-dot" notation) for clarity, but it's faster to do the algebra in sigma notation all the way through.
\begin{align*}
\displaystyle\sum_{i=50}^{100} \left(\dfrac{3}{5}\right)^i&=
 \left(\dfrac{3}{5}\right)^{50}+ \left(\dfrac{3}{5}\right)^{51}+ \left(\dfrac{3}{5}\right)^{52}+\cdots+ \left(\dfrac{3}{5}\right)^{100}\\
 &=
 \left(\dfrac{3}{5}\right)^{50}\left[1+ \left(\dfrac{3}{5}\right)+ \left(\dfrac{3}{5}\right)^{2}+\cdots+ \left(\dfrac{3}{5}\right)^{50}\right]
\\
&= \left(\dfrac{3}{5}\right)^{50}\dfrac{1-\left(\frac{3}{5}\right)^{51}}{1-\frac{3}{5}}\\
&=\dfrac{5}{2}\left(\dfrac{3}{5}\right)^{50}\left[1-\left(\frac{3}{5}\right)^{51}\right].
\end{align*}

\item[Solution 2:]
In this solution, we write our given expression as the difference of two sums, both starting at $i=0$.
\begin{align*}
\displaystyle\sum_{i=50}^{100} \left(\dfrac{3}{5}\right)^i&=
\displaystyle\sum_{i=0}^{100} \left(\dfrac{3}{5}\right)^i-
\displaystyle\sum_{i=0}^{49} \left(\dfrac{3}{5}\right)^i\\
&=\dfrac{1-\left(\frac{3}{5}\right)^{101}}{1-\frac{3}{5}} -
\dfrac{1-\left(\frac{3}{5}\right)^{50}}{1-\frac{3}{5}} \\
&=\dfrac{5}{2}\left[\left(\frac{3}{5}\right)^{50}-\left(\frac{3}{5}\right)^{101}\right]\\
&=\dfrac{5}{2}\left(\dfrac{3}{5}\right)^{50}\left[1-\left(\frac{3}{5}\right)^{51}\right].
\end{align*}
\end{description}
\item Before we can use the equations in Theorem~\eref{CLP101}{thm:INTspecialSums}, we'll need to do a little simplification.
\begin{align*}
\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{10} \left(i^2-3i+5\right)&=
\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{10} i^2
+\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{10} -3i
+\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{10}5\\
&=
\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{10} i^2
-3\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{10} i
+5\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{10}1\\
&=
\frac{1}{6}(10)(11)(21)
-3\left(\frac{1}{2}(10\cdot 11)\right)
+5\cdot 10\\
&=270
\end{align*}
\item As in part (c), we'll simplify first. The first part (shown here in red) is a geometric sum, but it does not start at $1=\left(\frac{1}{e}\right)^0$.
\begin{align*}
\displaystyle\sum_{n=1}^{b}\left[\textcolor{red}{ \left(\frac{1}{e}\right)^n}\textcolor{black}+
\,\textcolor{blue}{en^3}\right]&=
\color{red}\displaystyle\sum_{n=1}^{b} \left(\frac{1}{e}\right)^n\color{black}+\color{blue}
\displaystyle\sum_{n=1}^{b}en^3\\
&=\color{red}
\displaystyle\sum_{n=0}^{b} \left(\frac{1}{e}\right)^{n}-1
\color{black}+
\color{blue}e\displaystyle\sum_{n=1}^{b}n^3\\
&=\color{red}
\dfrac{1-\left(\frac{1}{e}\right)^{b+1}}{1-\frac{1}{e}}-1
\color{black}+
\color{blue}e\left[\frac{1}{2}b(b+1)\right]^2\\
              &=\color{red}
              \dfrac{\frac{1}{e}-\left(\frac{1}{e}\right)^{b+1}}{1-\frac{1}{e}}
              \color{black}+
              \color{blue}e\left[\frac{1}{2}b(b+1)\right]^2\\
&=\textcolor{red}{\dfrac{1-\left(\frac{1}{e}\right)^b}{e-1}}+\textcolor{blue}{\frac{e}{4}\left[b(b+1)\right]^2}
\end{align*}
\end{enumerate}
\end{solution}

golden_answer:
\begin{solution}
We identify the given sum as the right Riemann sum
$\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n} f(a+i\De x)\Delta  x$,
with $a=0$ (that's specified in the statement of the question). Since $\frac{4}{n}$ is multiplied in every term, and is also multiplied by $i$, we let
 $\Delta x = \frac{4}{n}$. Then $x_i^* = a+i\De x=\frac{4i}{n}$
and $f(x) = \sin^2 (2 + x)$. So, $b=a+n\De x=0+n\cdot\frac{4}{n}=4$.
\end{solution}
model_response:
**Solution:**

The limit is a Riemann sum, which approximates the area below a graph of $y=f(x)$ integrated over the interval $[0,b]$ using $n$ rectangles of width $\frac{b}{n}$ and height $f(a_i)$ for each rectangle, where $a_i$ is the endpoint of the interval $[0,b]$ corresponding to the $i$-th rectangle.

In this case,

$$f(x) = \sin^2(2+x)$$

$$b = \infty$$

Final Answer: The value of the limit is equal to the area below the graph of $y = \sin^2(2+x)$ integrated over the interval $[0, \infty]$.
evaluation_reason: The model correctly identified $f(x) = \sin^2(2+x)$. However, the value for $b$ is incorrect. Based on the Riemann sum identification, where $\Delta x = \frac{4}{n}$ and the interval is $[0,b]$ (so $a=0$), we have $\Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n} = \frac{b-0}{n} = \frac{b}{n}$. Equating $\frac{b}{n} = \frac{4}{n}$ yields $b=4$. The model incorrectly states $b=\infty$.

$$\int_a^b x\, \dee{x}$$

can be interpreted as the signed area of the triangle with vertices at $(a,0)$, $(b,0)$, and $(b,x)$ for any $x \in [a,b]$. The area of this triangle is given by the formula

$$\text{Area}=\frac{1}{2}bh$$

where $h$ is the height of the triangle and $b$ is its base. In this case, the height is $x$ and the base is $b-a$. So, the area of the triangle is

$$\text{Area}=\frac{1}{2}(b-a)x$$

Therefore, the integral

$$\int_a^b x\, \dee{x}=\frac{1}{2}(b-a)x^2$$

Final Answer:

$$\int_a^b x\, \dee{x}=\frac{1}{2}(b-a)x^2$$
evaluation_reason: The model incorrectly identifies the geometric shape as a triangle; it is a trapezoid. Furthermore, the model's derived "area" formula of $\frac{1}{2}(b-a)x^2$ is fundamentally incorrect for a definite integral, as a definite integral should evaluate to a numerical value (or an expression in terms of $a$ and $b$), not an expression containing the variable of integration $x$. problem_statement:
\begin{question}[2016Q1]
Estimate $\displaystyle\int_{-1}^5 x^3\,\,\dee{x}$ using three approximating rectangles
and left hand end points.
\end{question}
model_response:
**Solution:**

The area of a rectangle is given by the formula A = h*w, where h is the height and w is the width. To estimate the area of a function using approximating rectangles, we first divide the interval of integration into equal-width subintervals. Then, we find the height of each rectangle by evaluating the function at the left endpoint of each subinterval. Finally, we multiply the height of each rectangle by its width and sum the areas of all the rectangles to estimate the area of the function.

In this problem, we have

$$\int_{-1}^5 x^3\ dx$$

We divide the interval [-1, 5] into three subintervals of width 2. The left endpoints of each subinterval are -1, 1, and 3. The height of each rectangle is given by the function value at the left endpoint of each subinterval:

$$h_1 = f(-1) = -1$$

$$h_2 = f(1) = 1$$

$$h_3 = f(3) = 9$$

The area of each rectangle is

$$A_i = h_i*w = -1*2 = -2$$

$$A_2 = h_2*w = 1*2 = 2$$

$$A_3 = h_3*w = 9*2 = 18$$

The total area of the approximating rectangles is

$$A_T = -2 + 2 + 18 = 18$$

Final Answer: 18
evaluation_reason: The model correctly identified the interval, number of rectangles, width, and left endpoints. However, it made a calculation error when evaluating the function $f(x) = x^3$ at $x=3$. It incorrectly calculated $f(3) = 3^2 = 9$ instead of $f(3) = 3^3 = 27$. This led to an incorrect height for the third rectangle and an incorrect final sum (18 instead of 54).

model_response:
**Solution:**

The left and right Riemann sums approximate the area under the curve of $f(x)$ between $a$ and $b$ using the sum of the areas of rectangles. The midpoint Riemann sum approximates the area under the curve of $f(x)$ between $a$ and $b$ using the sum of the areas of rectangles with midpoints on the curve. If we average the left and right Riemann sums, we are essentially taking the average of the two endpoints of each rectangle, which is the same as the midpoint of the rectangle. Therefore, the average of the left and right Riemann sums is equal to the midpoint Riemann sum.

**Final Answer:**

Final Answer: The average of the left and right Riemann sums for $\displaystyle\int_a^b f(x)\ \dee{x}$ using $n$ rectangles is equal to the midpoint Riemann sum using $n$ rectangles.
evaluation_reason: The model's final answer correctly states that the average of the left and right Riemann sums for a linear function is equal to the midpoint Riemann sum. The reasoning provided by the model correctly identifies the core mathematical property: "If we average the left and right Riemann sums, we are essentially taking the average of the two endpoints of each rectangle, which is the same as the midpoint of the rectangle." This statement implicitly relies on the fact that for a linear function $f(x)$, the function value at the midpoint of an interval is the average of the function values at its endpoints, i.e., $f\left(\frac{x_1+x_2}{2}\right) = \frac{f(x_1)+f(x_2)}{2}$. While the gold answer provides a detailed algebraic proof using $f(x)=mx+c$, the model's conceptual explanation accurately conveys the underlying mathematical reason. Given the instruction to allow leeway for a TA grader, this concise explanation is acceptable for arriving at the correct conclusion for a True/False question.

\begin{solution}
We let $f(x)=2\tan(x)-x-1$. Then $f(x)$ is a continuous function on the interval $(-\pi/2, \pi/2)$ since $\tan(x)=\sin(x)/\cos(x)$ is continuous on this interval, while $x+1$ is a polynomial and therefore continuous for all real numbers.

We find a value $a\in (-\pi/2,\pi/2)$ such that $f(a)<0$. We observe immediately that $a=0$ works since
$$f(0)=2\tan(0)-0-1=0-1=-1<0.$$

We find a value $b\in (-\pi/2, \pi/2)$ such that $f(b)>0$. We see that $b=\pi/4$ works since
$$f(\pi/4)=2\tan(\pi/4) -\pi/4 - 1=2-\pi/4 - 1=1-\pi/4=(4-\pi)/4>0,$$
because $3<\pi<4$.

So, because $f(x)$ is continuous on $[0,\pi/4]$ and $f(0)<0$ while $f(\pi/4)>0$, then the Intermediate Value Theorem guarantees the existence of a real number $c\in (0,\pi/4)$ such that $f(c)=0$.
\end{solution}

There exists at least one real number $c$ such that $2\tan(c)=c+1$.

golden_answer:
\begin{solution}
The top surface $x^2+y^2+z^2=2$ meets the bottom surface
$z=x^2+y^2$ when $z$ obeys $x^2+y^2=z=2-z^2$. That is, when 
$0=z^2+z-2=(z-1)(z+2)$. The root $z=-2$ is inconsistent with 
$z=x^2+y^2\ge 0$. So the top and bottom surfaces meet at the circle
$z=1$, $x^2+y^2=1$.

In polar coordinates, the top surface is $z^2=2-r^2$, or equivalently
$z=\sqrt{2-r^2}$, and the bottom surface is $z=r^2$. So the height of the volume
above the point with polar coordinates $(r,\theta)$ is
$\sqrt{2-r^2}-r^2$ and
\begin{align*}
\text{Volume}&=\int_0^1\dee{r}\int_0^{2\pi} \dee{\theta}\ r\,\big[\sqrt{2-r^2}-r^2\big]
=2\pi \int_0^1\dee{r}\ r\,\big[\sqrt{2-r^2}-r^2\big]\\
&=2\pi \left[-\frac{1}{3}{(2-r^2)}^{3/2}-\frac{r^4}{4}\right]_0^1
=2\pi \left[-\frac{1}{3}-\frac{1}{4}+\frac{1}{3}2^{3/2}\right] \\
&=\pi \left[\frac{4}{3}\sqrt{2}-\frac{7}{6}\right] 
\approx 2.26
\end{align*}
In Cartesian coordinates
\begin{align*}
\text{Volume}&=4\int_0^1\dee{x}\int_0^{\sqrt{1-x^2}} \dee{y}\ 
                       \big[\sqrt{2-x^2-y^2}-x^2-y^2\big]
\end{align*}
The $y$ integral can be done using the substitution $y=\sqrt{2-x^2}\cos t$,
but it is easier to use polar coordinates.
\end{solution}

$$V=\int_0^a\int_0^b\int_0^{f(x,y)}dxdydz$$

where $a$ and $b$ are the bounds of the domain in the $xy$-plane.

In this problem, the surface is the sphere $x^2+y^2+z^2=2$ and the plane surface is $z=x^2+y^2$. The bounds of the domain in the $xy$-plane are given by the circle $x^2+y^2=2$.

Therefore, the volume is

$$V=\int_0^2\int_0^{\sqrt{2-x^2}}\int_0^{\sqrt{2-x^2-y^2}}dxdydz$$

Evaluating this integral, we get

**Final Answer:**

$$V=\frac{4\pi}{3}\sqrt{2}+2\pi$$

\end{itemize}

\begin{itemize}
\item
has $\rho=\sqrt{x^2+y^2+z^2}
       =\sqrt{\left(-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)^2
               +\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)^2
               +\left(\sqrt{3}\right)^2}=\sqrt{4}=2$
and
\item
has $\sqrt{3}=z=\rho\cos\varphi = 2\cos\varphi$ so that
$\cos\varphi = \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}$ and $\varphi=\frac{\pi}{6}$
and
\item
has $-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}=x=\rho\sin\varphi\cos\theta 
= 2\big(\frac{1}{2}\big)\cos\theta$ 
so that $\cos\theta = -\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}$. As 
$\left(-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}},\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)$ is in the second
quadrant, we have $\frac{\pi}{2}\le\theta\le\pi$ and so 
$\theta=\frac{3\pi}{4}$.  

\end{itemize}

\end{solution}

problem_statement:
\begin{question}
If $t_0$ is a local minimum or maximum of the smooth function $\ f(t)\ $
of one variable ($t$ runs over all real numbers) then $\ f'(t_0)=0.$
Derive an analogous necessary condition for $\vx_0$ to be a local minimum
or maximium of the smooth function $\ g(\vx)\ $ \textbf{restricted} to points on
the line $\ \vx=\va+t\vd\ .$ The test should involve the gradient 
of $g(\vx)$. 

\end{question}
golden_answer:
\begin{solution}
 Define $f(t)=g(\va+t\vd)$ and determine $t_0$ by 
$\vx_0=\va+t_0\vd$. Then $f'(t)=\vnabla g(\va+t\vd)\cdot\vd$. 
To see this, write $\va=\llt a_1,a_2,a_3\rgt$ and $\vd=\llt d_1,d_2,d_3\rgt$.
Then 
\begin{equation*}
f(t)=g(a_1+td_1,a_2+td_2,a_3+td_3)
\end{equation*} 
So, by the chain rule,
\begin{align*}
f'(t) &= \pdiff{g}{x}(a_1+td_1,a_2+td_2,a_3+td_3)\,d_1
       +\pdiff{g}{y}(a_1+td_1,a_2+td_2,a_3+td_3)\,d_2 \\&\hskip2in
       +\pdiff{g}{z}(a_1+td_1,a_2+td_2,a_3+td_3)\,d_3 \\
     &=\vnabla g(\va+t\vd)\cdot\vd
\end{align*}
Then $\vx_0$ is a local
max or min of the restriction of $g$  to the specified line if and only
if $t_0$ is a local max or min of $f(t)$. If so, $f'(t_0)$  necessarily
vanishes. So if $\vx_0$ is a local
max or min of the restriction of $g$  to the specified line,
then $\vnabla g(\vx_0)\cdot\vd=0$, i.e. $\vnabla g(\vx_0)\perp\vd$, and $\vx_0=\va+t_0\vd$ for some $t_0$. 
The second condition is to ensure that $x_0$ lies on the line.
\end{solution}
model_response:
**Answer:**

The gradient of $g(\vx)$ with respect to $t$ is given by

$$\frac{\partial g(\vx)}{\partial t}=\frac{\partial g(\vx)}{\partial x_1}\frac{\partial x_1}{\partial t}+\frac{\partial g(\vx)}{\partial x_2}\frac{\partial x_2}{\partial t}= \frac{\partial g(\vx)}{\partial t}=v_1\frac{\partial g(\vx)}{\partial x_1}+v_2\frac{\partial g(\vx)}{\partial x_2}=0$$

where $v_1$ and $v_2$ are the components of the unit vector $\vec{v}=\frac{\partial \vx}{\partial t}$.

Therefore, if $t_0$ is a local minimum or maximum of the function $f(t)=g(\va+t\vec{v})$ then

$$\frac{\partial g(\vx_0)}{\partial t}=0$$

Final Answer: If $t_0$ is a local minimum or maximum of the smooth function $f(t)=g(\va+t\vec{v})$ then

$$\frac{\partial g(\vx_0)}{\partial t}=0$$
evaluation_reason:
The question asks for a necessary condition that "should involve the gradient of g(x)".
The Gold Answer correctly derives and states the condition as $\vnabla g(\vx_0)\cdot\vd=0$, which explicitly involves the gradient $\vnabla g(\vx_0)$ and the direction vector $\vd$.

The Model's final answer is $\frac{\partial g(\vx_0)}{\partial t}=0$. While this statement is mathematically correct in the context of the defined function $f(t)=g(\va+t\vec{v})$, it does not explicitly express the condition in terms of the gradient $\vnabla g(\vx_0)$ and the direction vector $\vd$, as requested by the problem. One must perform the chain rule expansion (which the model attempts but executes poorly in its derivation) to see the involvement of the gradient.

Furthermore, the model's derivation contains significant flaws and confusing notation:
1.  It incorrectly refers to $\frac{\partial g(\vx)}{\partial t}$ as "The gradient of $g(\vx)$ with respect to $t$". The gradient is a vector of partial derivatives with respect to spatial coordinates, not a scalar derivative with respect to `t`.
2.  The line `$$\frac{\partial g(\vx)}{\partial t}=\frac{\partial g(\vx)}{\partial x_1}\frac{\partial x_1}{\partial t}+\frac{\partial g(\vx)}{\partial x_2}\frac{\partial x_2}{\partial t}= \frac{\partial g(\vx)}{\partial t}=v_1\frac{\partial g(\vx)}{\partial x_1}+v_2\frac{\partial g(\vx)}{\partial x_2}=0$$` is mathematically ill-formed. It equates the derivative to itself and then to 0, implying the derivative is always zero, which is incorrect. The derivative is only zero at a critical point.
3.  The model introduces $\vec{v}$ as a "unit vector" which is incorrect; $\vec{v}$ (or $\vd$) is simply the direction vector of the line and is not necessarily a unit vector.

Due to the lack of explicit gradient involvement in the final answer and the significantly flawed derivation, the model's answer is considered incorrect.

problem_statement:
\begin{question}[M200 2013D] %4
Find the minimum of the function $h(x,y) = -4x - 2y + 6$ on the closed 
bounded domain defined by $x^2 + y^2 \le 1$.
\end{question}
model_response:
**Solution:**

The function $h(x,y) = -4x - 2y + 6$ is defined on the closed bounded domain $D = \{ (x,y) \in \mathbb{R}^2 : x^2 + y^2 \leq 1 \}$. To find the minimum of $h(x,y)$ on $D$, we first find the critical points of $h(x,y)$ within the domain. To do this, we find the partial derivatives of $h(x,y)$ with respect to $x$ and $y$, set them equal to 0, and solve the resulting system of equations.

The critical points of $h(x,y)$ within the domain are $$\left( \pm \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}, \pm \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \right)$$

The minimum of $h(x,y)$ on $D$ is then found by evaluating $h(x,y)$ at these critical points and selecting the minimum value.

**Final Answer:**

The minimum of the function $h(x,y) = -4x - 2y + 6$ on the closed bounded domain defined by $x^2 + y^2 \leq 1$ is

$$-6$$
evaluation_reason:
The model's final answer of $-6$ does not match the gold answer of $6-2\sqrt{5}$. The gold answer is approximately $1.528$, while the model's answer is $-6$.
The model's approach is also fundamentally flawed. The function $h(x,y) = -4x - 2y + 6$ is a linear function, and its gradient $\nabla h = \langle -4, -2 \rangle$ is never zero. This means there are no critical points in the interior of the domain. The model incorrectly states that the critical points are $(\pm \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}, \pm \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}})$. Consequently, the minimum must occur on the boundary, which the model fails to analyze.

problem_statement:
\begin{question} [M200 2001A] % 4
Consider the function 
$
g(x,y)=x^2-10y-y^2
.$ 
\begin{enumerate}[(a)]
\item
Find and classify  all critical points of $g$.

\item 
Find the absolute extrema of $g$ on the bounded region given by
\begin{equation*}
x^2+4y^2\le 16,\ y\le 0
\end{equation*}
\end{enumerate}
\end{question}
golden_answer:
\begin{solution}
(a)
We have
\begin{alignat*}{5}
g(x,y)&=x^2-10y-y^2 \qquad&
g_x(x,y)&=2x \qquad&
g_{xx}(x,y)&=2\\
 & & g_y(x,y)&=-10-2y\qquad &
g_{yy}(x,y)&=-2 \\
 & & & &g_{xy}(x,y)&=0
\end{alignat*}
At a critical point
\begin{align*}
g_x(x,y)=g_y(x,y)=0
\iff 2x=0\text{ and }-10-2y=0
\iff (x,y)=(0,-5)
\end{align*}
Since $g_{xx}(0,-5)g_{yy}(0,-5)-g_{xy}(0,-5)^2=2\times(-2)-0^2<0$,
the critical point is a saddle point.

(b)
The extrema must be either on the boundary of the region
or in the interior of the region. 
\begin{itemize}
\item 
On the semi-elliptical part of the boundary $-2\le y\le 0$ 
and $x^2+4y^2=16$ so that $g=x^2-10y-y^2=16-10y-5y^2=21-5(y+1)^2$. This has 
a minimum value of 16 (at $y=0,-2$) and a maximum value of 21 (at $y=-1$).
You could also come to this conclusion by checking the critical point
of  $16-10y-5y^2$ (i.e. solving $\diff{}{y}(16-10y-5y^2)=0$)
and checking the end points of the allowed interval (namely $y=0$ and $y=-2$).

\item 
On the flat part of the boundary $y=0$ and
$-4\le x\le 4$ so that $g=x^2$.  
The smallest value is taken when $x=0$ and is $0$ and the largest value
is taken when $x=\pm 4$ and is $16$.
\item 
If an extremum is in the interior of the plate,
it must be at a critical point of $g(x,y)$. The only critical point is
not in the prescribed region.
\end{itemize}
Here is a table giving all candidates for extrema:
\begin{center}
\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.3}
     \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
     \hline
       $(x,y)$  & $g(x,y)$ \\ \hline
       $(0,-2)$ & $16$ \\ \hline
       $(\pm 4,0)$ & $16$ \\ \hline
       $(\pm \sqrt{12},-1)$ & $21$ \\ \hline 
       $(0,0)$  & $0$ \\ \hline
     \end{tabular}
\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.0}
\end{center}
From the table the smallest value of $g$ is $0$ at $(0,0)$
and the largest value is $21$ at $(\pm 2\sqrt{3},-1)$.
\end{solution}
model_response:
**Solution:**

The partial derivatives of $g$ are

$$\frac{\partial g}{\partial x}=2x, \frac{\partial g}{\partial y}=-2y-10$$

Setting these equal to 0 and solving for $x$ and $y$, we find the critical points are

$$\left(0, -5\right), \left(\sqrt{2}, -5\right), \left(-\sqrt{2}, -5\right)$$

At these critical points, we have

$$g(0, -5)= -10, \space g(\sqrt{2}, -5)= -10, \space g(-\sqrt{2}, -5)= -10$$

Therefore, the absolute extrema of $g$ on the bounded region are

**Final Answer:**

The absolute extrema of the function 

$$g(x,y)=x^2-10y-y^2$$

on the bounded region given by

$$\x^2+4y^2\le 16, \space y\le 0$$

are

$$g(0, -5)= -10, \space g(\sqrt{2}, -5)= -10, \space g(-\sqrt{2}, -5)= -10$$
evaluation_reason:
The model's answer is incorrect for both parts of the question.

For part (a):
1.  The model correctly calculates the partial derivatives `g_x = 2x` and `g_y = -2y - 10`.
2.  However, when setting these to zero to find critical points, `2x=0` gives `x=0` and `-2y-10=0` gives `y=-5`. Thus, the *only* critical point is `(0, -5)`. The model incorrectly lists `(√2, -5)` and `(-√2, -5)` as critical points.
3.  The model does not classify the critical point(s), which was a requirement of part (a).

For part (b):
1.  The model only lists values of `g` at the incorrectly identified critical points from part (a) as the absolute extrema.
2.  None of these points `(0, -5)`, `(√2, -5)`, `(-√2, -5)` are within the specified bounded region `x^2+4y^2 ≤ 16, y ≤ 0`. For example, for `(0,-5)`, `0^2 + 4(-5)^2 = 100`, which is not less than or equal to `16`. Therefore, these points cannot be the absolute extrema on the given region.
3.  The model completely fails to apply the method for finding absolute extrema on a bounded region, which involves checking critical points *within* the region and analyzing the function on the boundary of the region.

model_response:
**Solution:**

The partial derivatives of $f(x,y)$ are given by

$$f_x(x,y)= \frac{\partial f(x,y)}{\partial x}=e^y$$

$$f_y(x,y)= \frac{\partial f(x,y)}{\partial y}=e^x$$

In order to find $f(x,y)$, we need to integrate both sides of these equations with respect to $x$ and $y$, respectively.

Integrating with respect to $x$, we get

$$f(x,y)=e^x+C(y)$$

where $C(y)$ is a function of $y$.

Integrating with respect to $y$, we get

$$C(y)=e^y+K$$

where $K$ is a constant.

Therefore, the function $f(x,y)$ is

$$f(x,y)=e^x+e^y+K$$

where $K$ is a constant.

**Final Answer:**

Final Answer: $f(x,y)=e^x+e^y+K$, where $K$ is a constant.
evaluation_reason:
The model's final answer $f(x,y)=e^x+e^y+K$ does not satisfy the given conditions.
If $f(x,y)=e^x+e^y+K$, then $f_x(x,y) = e^x$ and $f_y(x,y) = e^y$.
However, the question states $f_x(x,y)=e^y$ and $f_y(x,y)=e^x$. These are inconsistent with the model's proposed solution.

Furthermore, the model makes an error in its integration step. If $f_x(x,y)=e^y$, then integrating with respect to $x$ yields $f(x,y) = \int e^y dx = xe^y + C(y)$, not $e^x+C(y)$ as stated by the model.

The correct approach, as demonstrated by the gold answer, is to check the equality of mixed partial derivatives (Clairaut's Theorem).
Given $f_x(x,y)=e^y$ and $f_y(x,y)=e^x$:
$f_{xy}(x,y) = \frac{\partial}{\partial y}(f_x(x,y)) = \frac{\partial}{\partial y}(e^y) = e^y$
$f_{yx}(x,y) = \frac{\partial}{\partial x}(f_y(x,y)) = \frac{\partial}{\partial x}(e^x) = e^x$
Since $e^y \neq e^x$ for all $x,y$, the mixed partial derivatives are not equal, which implies that no such function $f(x,y)$ exists. The model failed to identify this fundamental property and incorrectly concluded that a function exists.

**Solution:**

The given equation is

$$e^z + yz = x + y$$

Taking the derivative with respect to $x$, we get

$$\frac{\partial z}{\partial x} = \frac{\partial e^z + yz}{\partial x} = \frac{e^z + y}{e^z + Y}$$

where $Y$ is the derivative of $z$ with respect to $y$.

Using the linear approximation formula at the point $(1,0)$, we have

$$\Delta z = \frac{\partial z}{\partial x} \Delta x + \frac{\partial z}{\partial y} \Delta y$$

where

$$\Delta z = f(a) - f(a_0, b_0)$$

$$\Delta x = x - a_0$$

$$\Delta y = y - b_0$$

Substituting these values into the equation, we get

$$\Delta z = \frac{e^{a_0} + b_0}{e^{a_0} + Y} \Delta x + \frac{\partial z}{\partial y} \Delta y$$

Final Answer: The approximate value of $f(0.99,0.01)$ is

$$f(0.99,0.01) \approx 0.99 + 0.01 = 1.00$$
evaluation_reason:
The model's solution for both parts (a) and (b) contains significant errors.

For part (a), the model attempts to find $\frac{\partial z}{\partial x}$ but provides an incorrect expression: $\frac{e^z + y}{e^z + Y}$. The 'Y' in the denominator is undefined and makes the expression nonsensical. Furthermore, it does not calculate $\frac{\partial z}{\partial y}$ or present the full differential $\dee{z} = f_x \dee{x} + f_y \dee{y}$.

For part (b), the model fails to correctly evaluate $f(1,0)$ from the implicit equation, which is $f(1,0)=0$. It also fails to correctly evaluate the partial derivatives $f_x(1,0)$ and $f_y(1,0)$ at the point $(1,0)$. The linear approximation formula is stated correctly, but its application is flawed due to the errors in calculating the partial derivatives and the base value $f(1,0)$.

The final approximated value of $f(0.99, 0.01)$ given by the model is $1.00$, which is the sum of the input $x$ and $y$ values. This is fundamentally incorrect. The gold answer correctly computes this value to be $0$.

problem_statement:
\begin{question}[M200 2000D] %2
Use differentials to estimate the volume of metal in a closed
metal can with diameter 8cm and height 12cm if the metal is 0.04cm thick. 
\end{question}
golden_answer:
\begin{solution}
The volume of a cylinder of diameter $d$ and height $h$ 
is $V(d,h)=\pi\big(\frac{d}{2}\big)^2h$. The wording of the question is
a bit ambiguous in that it does not specify if the given dimensions are
inside dimensions or outside dimensions. Assume that they are outside
dimensions. Then the volume of the can, including the metal, is $V(8,12)$
and the volume of the interior, excluding the metal, is 
\begin{align*}
V(8-2\times0.04\,,\,12-2\times 0.04)
&\approx  V(8,12)
+V_d(8,12)(-2\times 0.04)
+V_h(8,12)(-2\times 0.04)\\
&=V(8,12)
+\frac{1}{2}\pi\times 8\times 12\times(-2\times 0.04)
+\pi\left(\frac{8}{2}\right)^2\!\!(-2\times 0.04)\\
&=V(8,12)
-\pi\times 128\times 0.04
\end{align*}
So the volume of metal is approximately $\pi\times 128\times 0.04=
5.12\pi\approx 16.1$cc. (To this level of approximation, it doesn't matter
whether the dimensions are inside or outside dimensions.)
\end{solution}
model_response:
**Solution:**

The volume of a closed metal can is given by the formula

$$V = \pi r^2 h$$

where V is the volume, r is the radius, and h is the height.

We know that the diameter of the can is 8cm, so the radius is 4cm. We also know that the height of the can is 12cm and the thickness of the metal is 0.04cm. So, the total volume of metal in the can is

$$V = \pi (4^2) (12) = 100\pi cm^3$$

Final Answer: The total volume of metal in the can is 100π cm^3.
evaluation_reason: The model completely failed to answer the question as posed. The question explicitly asks to "Use differentials to estimate the volume of metal". The model instead calculates the total volume of the can using the given (outer) dimensions, ignoring the metal thickness and the instruction to use differentials. The final answer $192\pi$ cm³ is the volume of the entire can, not the volume of the metal. The gold answer correctly uses differentials to find the volume of metal as $5.12\pi$ cm³.

golden_answer:
\begin{solution}
 The basic assumption is that the three quantites $x$, $y$
and $z$ are not independent. Given any two of them, the third is uniquely
determined. They are assumed to satisfy a relationship
$F(x,y,z)=0$, which can be solved to
\begin{itemize}\itemsep1pt \parskip0pt \parsep0pt %\itemindent-15p
\item
determine $x$ as a function of $y$ and $z$ (say $x=f(y,z)$) and 
can alternatively be solved to
\item
determine $y$ as a function of $x$ and $z$ (say $y=g(x,z)$) and 
can alternatively be solved to
\item
determine $z$ as a function of $x$ and $y$
(say $z=h(x,y)$). 
\end{itemize}
As an example, if $F(x,y,z) = xyz-1$, then 
\begin{itemize}\itemsep1pt \parskip0pt \parsep0pt %\itemindent-15p
\item
$F(x,y,z)=xyz-1=0$ implies that $x=\frac{1}{yz}=f(y,z)$ and
\item
$F(x,y,z)=xyz-1=0$ implies that $y=\frac{1}{xz}=g(x,z)$ and
\item
$F(x,y,z)=xyz-1=0$ implies that $z=\frac{1}{xy}=h(x,y)$
\end{itemize}
In general, saying that  $F(x,y,z)=0$ determines $x=f(y,z)$ means that 
\begin{equation*}
F\big(f(y,z),y,z\big)=0
\tag{$*$}
\end{equation*}
for all $y$ and $z$. 
Set $\mathcal{F}(y,z)=F\big(f(y,z),y,z\big)$. Applying the chain rule to
$\mathcal{F}(y,z)=F\big(f(y,z),y,z\big)$ (with $y$ and $z$ independent variables) 
gives
\begin{align*}
\pdiff{\mathcal{F}}{z}(y,z) 
%&= \pdiff{F}{x}\big(f(y,z),y,z\big)\pdiff{f}{z}(y,z)
%+\pdiff{F}{z}\big(f(y,z),y,z\big)\diff{z}{z} \\
&= 
\pdiff{F}{x}\big(f(y,z),y,z\big)
\pdiff{f}{z}(y,z)
+\pdiff{F}{z}\big(f(y,z),y,z\big)
\end{align*}
The equation $(*)$ says that $\mathcal{F}(y,z)=F\big(f(y,z),y,z\big)=0$ 
for all $y$ and $z$.
So differentiating the equation $(*)$ with respect to 
$z$ gives
\begin{align*}
\pdiff{\mathcal{F}}{z}(y,z)&=\pdiff{F}{x}\big(f(y,z),y,z\big)
\pdiff{f}{z}(y,z)
+\pdiff{F}{z}\big(f(y,z),y,z\big)=0 \\
&\implies
\pdiff{f}{z}(y,z)
=-\frac{\pdiff{F}{z}\big(f(y,z),y,z\big)}{\pdiff{F}{x}\big(f(y,z),y,z\big)}
\end{align*}
for all $y$ and $z$. Similarly, differentiating 
$F\big(x,g(x,z),z\big)=0$ with respect to $x$ and
$F\big(x,y,h(x,y)\big)=0$ with respect to $y$ gives
\begin{align*}
\pdiff{g}{x}(x,z)
=-\frac{\pdiff{F}{x}\big(x,g(x,z),z\big)}{\pdiff{F}{y}\big(x,g(x,z),z\big)}\qquad
\pdiff{h}{y}(x,y)
=-\frac{\pdiff{F}{y}\big(x,y,h(x,y)\big)}{\pdiff{F}{z}\big(x,y,h(x,y)\big)}
\end{align*}
If $(x,y,z)$ is any point satisfying $F(x,y,z)=0$ 
(so that $x=f(y,z)$ and $y=g(x,z)$ and  $z=h(x,y)$), then
\begin{align*}
\pdiff{f}{z}(y,z)
=-\frac{\pdiff{F}{z}\big(x,y,z\big)}{\pdiff{F}{x}\big(x,y,z\big)}\qquad
\pdiff{g}{x}(x,z)
=-\frac{\pdiff{F}{x}\big(x,y,z\big)}{\pdiff{F}{y}\big(x,y,z\big)}\qquad
\pdiff{h}{y}(x,y)
=-\frac{\pdiff{F}{y}\big(x,y,z\big)}{\pdiff{F}{z}\big(x,y,z\big)}
\end{align*}
and
\begin{align*}
\pdiff{f}{z}(y,z)\ 
\pdiff{g}{x}(x,z)\ 
\pdiff{h}{y}(x,y)
&=-\frac{\pdiff{F}{z}\big(x,y,z\big)}{\pdiff{F}{x}\big(x,y,z\big)}\ 
\frac{\pdiff{F}{x}\big(x,y,z\big)}{\pdiff{F}{y}\big(x,y,z\big)}\ 
\frac{\pdiff{F}{y}\big(x,y,z\big)}{\pdiff{F}{z}\big(x,y,z\big)} \\
&=-1
\end{align*}
\end{solution}
model_response:
**Answer:**

The equation

$$\left(\pdiff{y}{x}\right)
\left(\pdiff{z}{y}\right)
\left(\pdiff{x}{z}\right)=-1$$

expresses the relationship between the partial derivatives of the variables x, y, and z with respect to each other. In other words, it states that the product of the partial derivatives of y with respect to x and z with respect to y, is equal to -1.

To prove that this equation is true, we can use the following chain rule:

$$\pdiff{x}{z}=\frac{\partial x}{\partial y}\frac{\partial y}{\partial z}\frac{\partial z}{\partial x}$$

This equation is derived from the following sequence of steps:

$$\frac{\partial x}{\partial y}=\frac{\partial x}{\partial z}\frac{\partial z}{\partial y}$$

$$\frac{\partial y}{\partial z}=\frac{\partial y}{\partial x}\frac{\partial x}{\partial z}$$

$$\Rightarrow \pdiff{x}{z}=\frac{\partial x}{\partial y}\frac{\partial y}{\partial z}\frac{\partial z}{\partial x}=-1$$

Therefore, the equation

$$\left(\pdiff{y}{x}\right)
\left(\pdiff{z}{y}\right)
\left(\pdiff{x}{z}\right)=-1$$

is proven to be true.

**Final Answer:**

Final Answer: The relationship between the partial derivatives of the variables x, y, and z with respect to each other is given by the equation

$$\left(\pdiff{y}{x}\right)
\left(\pdiff{z}{y}\right)
\left(\pdiff{x}{z}\right)=-1$$
evaluation_reason:
The model's explanation of the meaning of the equation is superficial and incomplete. It fails to mention the crucial context that the variables x, y, and z are interdependent, typically related by an implicit function F(x,y,z)=0, and that the partial derivatives imply certain variables are held constant (e.g., (∂y/∂x) implies z is held constant).

The proof provided by the model is fundamentally incorrect and demonstrates a misunderstanding of multivariable calculus and the chain rule for partial derivatives.
1.  The model states "we can use the following chain rule: $\pdiff{x}{z}=\frac{\partial x}{\partial y}\frac{\partial y}{\partial z}\frac{\partial z}{\partial x}$". This statement is itself the relationship that needs to be proven (or a rearrangement of it) and is not a standard chain rule that can be directly applied in this manner to prove the original identity.
2.  The subsequent steps "$\frac{\partial x}{\partial y}=\frac{\partial x}{\partial z}\frac{\partial z}{\partial y}$" and "$\frac{\partial y}{\partial z}=\frac{\partial y}{\partial x}\frac{\partial x}{\partial z}$" are also incorrect applications or interpretations of chain rules/inverse relations for partial derivatives.
3.  The model does not use implicit differentiation, which is the standard and correct method for proving this identity. Instead, it asserts the result based on incorrect premises.

problem_statement:
\begin{question}[M200 2005D] %2
Assume that $f(x,y)$ satisfies Laplace's equation 
$\frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x^2}+\frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial y^2}=0$.
Show that this is also the case for the composite function 
$g(s,t) = f (s - t, s + t)$. That is, show that
$\frac{\partial^2 g}{\partial s^2}+\frac{\partial^2 g}{\partial t^2}=0$.
You may assume that $f(x,y)$ is a smooth function so that the 
Chain Rule and Clairaut's Theorem on the equality of the mixed partial derivatives apply.
\end{question}
model_response:
**Answer:**

The partial derivatives of $g(s,t) = f (s - t, s + t)$ with respect to $s$ and $t$ are given by

$$\frac{\partial g}{\partial s}=\frac{\partial f}{\partial x}(s-t,s+t)\frac{\partial s}{\partial s}+\frac{\partial f}{\partial y}(s-t,s+t)\frac{\partial t}{\partial s}=f_x(s-t,s+t)  $$

$$\frac{\partial g}{\partial t}=\frac{\partial f}{\partial x}(s-t,s+t)\frac{\partial s}{\partial t}+\frac{\partial f}{\partial y}(s-t,s+t)\frac{\partial t}{\partial t}=f_y(s-t,s+t)  $$

Taking the partial derivative of both sides of the above equations with respect to $s$ and $t$, respectively, we get

$$\frac{\partial^2 g}{\partial s^2}=f_{xx}(s-t,s+t)+f_{xy}(s-t,s+t) \frac{\partial t}{\partial s}+f_{yy}(s-t,s+t) \frac{\partial t}{\partial s}=0$$

$$\frac{\partial^2 g}{\partial t^2}=f_{xx}(s-t,s+t) \frac{\partial s}{\partial t}+f_{xy}(s-t,s+t) \frac{\partial t}{\partial t}+f_{yy}(s-t,s+t)=0$$

Therefore, we have shown that

**Final Answer:**

$$\frac{\partial^2 g}{\partial s^2}+\frac{\partial^2 g}{\partial t^2}=0$$

for the composite function $g(s,t) = f (s - t, s + t)$, assuming that $f(x,y)$ is a smooth function that satisfies Laplace's equation.
evaluation_reason:
The model's calculation of the first partial derivatives $\frac{\partial g}{\partial s}$ and $\frac{\partial g}{\partial t}$ is incorrect.
Let $x = s-t$ and $y = s+t$.
The chain rule states $\frac{\partial g}{\partial s} = \frac{\partial f}{\partial x} \frac{\partial x}{\partial s} + \frac{\partial f}{\partial y} \frac{\partial y}{\partial s}$.
Here, $\frac{\partial x}{\partial s} = 1$ and $\frac{\partial y}{\partial s} = 1$.
So, $\frac{\partial g}{\partial s} = f_x(s-t, s+t) \cdot 1 + f_y(s-t, s+t) \cdot 1 = f_x + f_y$.
The model incorrectly states $\frac{\partial g}{\partial s}=f_x(s-t,s+t)$, omitting the $f_y$ term and misapplying the chain rule.

Similarly, for $\frac{\partial g}{\partial t}$, the chain rule states $\frac{\partial g}{\partial t} = \frac{\partial f}{\partial x} \frac{\partial x}{\partial t} + \frac{\partial f}{\partial y} \frac{\partial y}{\partial t}$.
Here, $\frac{\partial x}{\partial t} = -1$ and $\frac{\partial y}{\partial t} = 1$.
So, $\frac{\partial g}{\partial t} = f_x(s-t, s+t) \cdot (-1) + f_y(s-t, s+t) \cdot 1 = -f_x + f_y$.
The model incorrectly states $\frac{\partial g}{\partial t}=f_y(s-t,s+t)$, omitting the $-f_x$ term and misapplying the chain rule.

Because the first partial derivatives are incorrect, the subsequent calculations for the second partial derivatives are also incorrect and nonsensical. The model also prematurely sets the second derivatives to zero without showing the detailed application of the chain rule that would lead to the desired result. The derivation is fundamentally flawed.

problem_statement:
\begin{question}[M200 2012a] %3
Let $z = f(x, y)$, where $f(x, y)$ has continuous second-order partial derivatives, 
and
\begin{equation*}
f_x (2, 1) = 5, \qquad
f_y(2, 1) =-2, \qquad
f_{xx}(2, 1) = 2,\qquad
f_{xy}(2, 1) = 1, \qquad
f_{yy}(2, 1) = -4
\end{equation*}
Find 
$
\difftwo{}{t} z\big(x(t),y(t)\big)
$
when $x(t)=2t^2$, $y(t)=t^3$ and $t=1$.
\end{question}
golden_answer:
\begin{solution}
Write $w(t) = z\big(x(t),y(t)\big) = f\big(x(t),y(t)\big)$ with
$x(t)=2t^2$, $y(t)=t^3$.
We are to compute $\difftwo{w}{t}(1)$.
By the chain rule
\begin{align*}
\diff{w}{t}(t)&= \diff{}{t} f\big(x(t),y(t)\big) \\
  &= f_x(x(t)\,,\,y(t))\,\diff{x}{t}(t)
                     +f_y(x(t)\,,\,y(t))\,\diff{y}{t}(t) \\
  &= 4t\,f_x(x(t)\,,\,y(t))
                     +3t^2\,f_y(x(t)\,,\,y(t)) 
\end{align*}
By linearity, the product rule, and the chain rule,
\begin{align*}
\difftwo{}{t} f\big(x(t),y(t)\big) 
&= \diff{}{t}\left[4t\,f_x\big(x(t),y(t)\big) \right]
   +\diff{}{t}\left[3t^2\,f_y\big(x(t),y(t)\big) \right] \\
&= 4\,f_x\big(x(t),y(t)\big)  
   + \textcolor{blue}{4t \diff{}{t}\left[f_x\big(x(t),y(t)\big) \right] }
         \\&\hskip0.1in
   +6t\,f_y\big(x(t),y(t)\big) 
   +\textcolor{red}{3t^2\diff{}{t}\left[f_y\big(x(t),y(t)\big) \right]} \\
&= 4\,f_x(2t^2\,,\,t^3) 
          + \textcolor{blue}{4t\Big[f_{xx}\big(x(t),y(t)\big)\,\diff{x}{t}(t)
          + f_{xy}\big(x(t),y(t)\big)\,\diff{y}{t}(t)\Big]} \\
&\phantom{=} + 6t\,f_y(2t^2\,,\,t^3) 
          + \textcolor{red}{3t^2\Big[f_{yx}\big(x(t),y(t)\big)\,\diff{x}{t}(t) 
          + f_{yy}\big(x(t),y(t)\big)\,\diff{y}{t}(t)\Big]} \\
&= 4\,f_x(2t^2\,,\,t^3) 
          + \textcolor{blue}{16t^2\,f_{xx}(2t^2\,,\,t^3)
          + 12t^3\,f_{xy}(2t^2\,,\,t^3)} \\
&\phantom{=} + 6t\,f_y(2t^2\,,\,t^3) 
          + \textcolor{red}{12t^3\,f_{yx}(2t^2\,,\,t^3) 
          + 9t^4\,f_{yy}(2t^2\,,\,t^3)} 
\end{align*}
In particular, when $t=1$, and since $f_{xy}(2, 1)=f_{yx}(2, 1)$,
\begin{align*}
\left.\difftwo{}{t} f\big(x(t),y(t)\big) \right|_{t=1}
&= 4\,(5) 
          +\textcolor{blue}{ 16\,(2)
          + 12\,(1)} \\
&\phantom{=} + 6\,(-2) 
          + \textcolor{red}{12\,(1)
          + 9\,(-4)} \\
&=28 
\end{align*}
\end{solution}
